sn56.16:0.2.eng: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.16:1.1.pli: “Dhāretha no tumhe, bhikkhave, mayā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānī”ti?
sn56.16:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, do you remember the four noble truths that I taught?”

sn56.16:1.2.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn56.16:1.2.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha:

sn56.16:1.3.pli: “ahaṃ kho, bhante, dhāremi bhagavatā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānī”ti.

sn56.16:2.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, dhāresi mayā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānī”ti?

sn56.16:2.2.pli: “Dukkhaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ dhāremi.
sn56.16:2.2.eng: “Sir, I remember that suffering is the first noble truth you’ve taught.

sn56.16:2.3.pli: Yo hi koci, bhante, samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.16:2.3.eng: For if any ascetic or brahmin should say this:

sn56.16:2.4.pli: ‘netaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yaṃ samaṇena gotamena desitaṃ.
sn56.16:2.4.eng: ‘What the ascetic Gotama teaches is not the first noble truth of suffering.

sn56.16:2.5.pli: Ahametaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paccakkhāya aññaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paññapessāmī’ti—
sn56.16:2.5.eng: I’ll deny this first noble truth of suffering and describe another first noble truth of suffering.’

sn56.16:2.7.eng: The origin of suffering … The cessation of suffering …

sn56.16:2.8.pli: dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ dhāremi.
sn56.16:2.8.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of suffering is the fourth noble truth you’ve taught.

sn56.16:2.9.pli: Yo hi koci, bhante, samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.16:2.9.eng: For if any ascetic or brahmin should say this:

sn56.16:2.10.pli: ‘netaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yaṃ samaṇena gotamena desitaṃ.
sn56.16:2.10.eng: ‘What the ascetic Gotama teaches is not the fourth noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.16:2.11.pli: Ahametaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paccakkhāya aññaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paññapessāmī’ti—
sn56.16:2.11.eng: I’ll deny this fourth noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering and describe another fourth noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

sn56.16:2.13.pli: Evaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, dhāremi bhagavatā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānī”ti.
sn56.16:2.13.eng: That’s how I remember the four noble truths as you’ve taught them.”

sn56.16:3.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, dhāresi mayā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānīti.
sn56.16:3.2.eng: It’s good that you remember the four noble truths as I’ve taught them.

sn56.16:3.3.pli: Dukkhaṃ kho, bhikkhu, mayā paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ, tathā naṃ dhārehi.
sn56.16:3.3.eng: Suffering is the first noble truth I’ve taught, and that’s how you should remember it.

sn56.16:3.4.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhu, samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.16:3.4.eng: For if any ascetic or brahmin should say this:

sn56.16:3.5.pli: ‘netaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yaṃ samaṇena gotamena desitaṃ.
sn56.16:3.5.eng: ‘What the ascetic Gotama teaches is not the first noble truth of suffering.

sn56.16:3.6.pli: Ahametaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paccakkhāya aññaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paññapessāmī’ti—
sn56.16:3.6.eng: I’ll deny this first noble truth of suffering and describe another first noble truth of suffering.’

sn56.16:3.10.pli: dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā kho, bhikkhu, mayā catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ desitaṃ, tathā naṃ dhārehi.
sn56.16:3.10.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of suffering is the fourth noble truth I’ve taught, and that’s how you should remember it.

sn56.16:3.11.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhu, samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.16:3.11.eng: For if any ascetic or brahmin should say this:

sn56.16:3.12.pli: ‘netaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yaṃ samaṇena gotamena desitaṃ.
sn56.16:3.12.eng: ‘What the ascetic Gotama teaches is not the fourth noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.16:3.13.pli: Ahametaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paccakkhāya aññaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ catutthaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paññapessāmī’ti—
sn56.16:3.13.eng: I’ll deny this fourth noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering and describe another fourth noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

sn56.16:3.15.pli: Evaṃ kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, dhārehi mayā cattāri ariyasaccāni desitānīti.
sn56.16:3.15.eng: That’s how you should remember the four noble truths as I’ve taught them.

sn56.16:4.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhu, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.16:4.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.17:0.2.eng: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.17:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn56.17:1.1.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn56.17:1.2.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘ignorance’.

sn56.17:1.4.eng: And how is an ignorant person defined?”

sn56.17:1.5.pli: “Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, dukkhe aññāṇaṃ, dukkhasamudaye aññāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhe aññāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇaṃ—
sn56.17:1.5.eng: “Not knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.17:1.7.eng: And this is how an ignorant person is defined.

sn56.17:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhu, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.17:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.18:0.2.eng: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.18:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn56.18:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn56.18:1.2.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘knowledge’.

sn56.18:1.4.eng: And how is a knowledgeable person defined?”

sn56.18:1.5.pli: “Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, dukkhe ñāṇaṃ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ—
sn56.18:1.5.eng: “Knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.18:1.7.eng: And this is how a knowledgeable person is defined.

sn56.18:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhu, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.18:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.19:0.2.eng: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.19:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I’ve declared: ‘This is the noble truth of suffering.’

sn56.19:1.2.pli: Tattha aparimāṇā vaṇṇā aparimāṇā byañjanā aparimāṇā saṅkāsanā:
sn56.19:1.2.eng: And there are limitless explanations, phrases, and expressions about that:

sn56.19:1.3.eng: ‘This is another way of saying that this is the noble truth of suffering.’

sn56.19:1.4.eng: I’ve declared: ‘This is the noble truth of the origin of suffering.’ …

sn56.19:1.5.eng: I’ve declared: ‘This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.’ …

sn56.19:1.6.pli: ‘idaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccan’ti, bhikkhave, mayā paññattaṃ.
sn56.19:1.6.eng: I’ve declared: ‘This is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

sn56.19:1.7.pli: Tattha aparimāṇā vaṇṇā aparimāṇā byañjanā aparimāṇā saṅkāsanā:
sn56.19:1.7.eng: And there are limitless explanations, phrases, and expressions about that:

sn56.19:1.8.eng: ‘This is another way of saying that this is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

sn56.19:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.19:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.2:1.2.eng: A mendicant in retreat truly understands.

sn56.2:1.4.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn56.2:1.4.eng: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.2:1.6.eng: A mendicant in retreat truly understands.

sn56.2:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.2:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation to understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.”

sn56.20:0.2.eng: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn56.20:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things are real, not unreal, not otherwise.

sn56.20:1.6.eng: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’ …

sn56.20:1.7.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni.
sn56.20:1.7.eng: These four things are real, not unreal, not otherwise.

sn56.20:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.20:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.21:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vajjīsu viharati koṭigāme.
sn56.21:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis at the village of Koṭi.

sn56.21:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn56.21:1.3.pli: “catunnaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasaccānaṃ ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.
sn56.21:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, due to not understanding and not penetrating four noble truths, both you and I have wandered and transmigrated for such a very long time.

sn56.21:2.2.pli: Dukkhassa, bhikkhave, ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

sn56.21:2.5.pli: dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.
sn56.21:2.5.eng: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.21:2.6.pli: Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ; ucchinnā bhavataṇhā, khīṇā bhavanetti; natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
sn56.21:2.6.eng: These noble truths of suffering, origin, cessation, and the path have been understood and comprehended. Craving for continued existence has been cut off; the leash to existence is ended; now there’ll be no more future lives.”

sn56.21:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn56.21:3.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn56.21:3.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn56.21:4.3.eng: we have transmigrated for a long time

sn56.21:4.4.eng: from one rebirth to the next.

sn56.21:5.1.eng: But now that these truths have been seen,

sn56.21:5.2.eng: the leash to existence is eradicated.

sn56.21:5.3.eng: The root of suffering is cut off,

sn56.21:5.4.eng: now there’ll be no more future lives.”

sn56.22:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti,
sn56.22:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.22:1.2.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca pana te āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn56.22:1.2.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn56.22:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti,
sn56.22:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.22:2.2.pli: te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn56.22:2.2.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn56.22:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn56.22:3.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn56.22:3.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn56.22:4.1.eng: “There are those who don’t understand suffering

sn56.22:5.1.eng: And they do not know the path

sn56.22:5.2.eng: that leads to the stilling of suffering.

sn56.22:5.4.eng: as well as the release by wisdom.

sn56.22:5.6.eng: they continue to be reborn and grow old.

sn56.22:6.1.eng: But there are those who understand suffering

sn56.22:7.2.eng: that leads to the stilling of suffering.

sn56.22:7.3.eng: They’re endowed with the heart’s release,

sn56.22:7.4.eng: as well as the release by wisdom.

sn56.22:7.6.eng: they don’t continue to be reborn and grow old.”

sn56.23:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.

sn56.23:1.4.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.23:1.5.eng: These are the four noble truths.

sn56.23:1.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhattā tathāgato ‘arahaṃ sammāsambuddho’ti vuccati.
sn56.23:1.6.eng: It is because he has truly understood these four noble truths that the Realized One is called ‘the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha’.

sn56.23:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.23:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.24:1.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambujjhiṃsu, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambujjhiṃsu.
sn56.24:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, whatever perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas truly awaken—in the past,

sn56.24:1.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambujjhissanti, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambujjhissanti.

sn56.24:1.4.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, etarahi arahanto sammāsambuddhā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambujjhanti, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambujjhanti.
sn56.24:1.4.eng: or present—all of them truly awaken to the four noble truths.

sn56.24:2.2.pli: Dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.
sn56.24:2.2.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.24:2.3.pli: Ye hi, keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambujjhiṃsu …pe…
sn56.24:2.3.eng: Whatever perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas truly awaken—in the past,

sn56.24:2.5.pli: abhisambujjhanti, sabbe te imāni cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambujjhanti.
sn56.24:2.5.eng: or present—all of them truly awaken to the four noble truths.

sn56.24:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.24:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.25:1.1.pli: “Jānatohaṃ, bhikkhave, passato āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi, no ajānato apassato.
sn56.25:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I say that the ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know or see.

sn56.25:1.2.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, jānato passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti?
sn56.25:1.2.eng: For one who knows and sees what?

sn56.25:1.3.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhan’ti, bhikkhave, jānato passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti jānato passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti jānato passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti jānato passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti.
sn56.25:1.3.eng: The ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.25:1.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṃ passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti.
sn56.25:1.4.eng: The ending of the defilements is for one who knows and sees this.

sn56.25:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.25:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.26:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, anukampeyyātha, ye ca sotabbaṃ maññeyyuṃ—mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā—te vo, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamayāya samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
sn56.26:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, those who you have sympathy for, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in the true comprehension of the four noble truths.

sn56.26:2.2.pli: Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa, dukkhasamudayassa ariyasaccassa, dukkhanirodhassa ariyasaccassa, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa.
sn56.26:2.2.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.26:2.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, anukampeyyātha, ye ca sotabbaṃ maññeyyuṃ—mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā—te vo, bhikkhave, imesaṃ catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamayāya samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
sn56.26:2.3.eng: Those who you have sympathy for, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in the true comprehension of these four noble truths.

sn56.26:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.26:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.27:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.

sn56.27:1.3.pli: Dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ—
sn56.27:1.3.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.27:1.4.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri ariyasaccāni tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni;
sn56.27:1.4.eng: These four noble truths are real, not unreal, not otherwise.

sn56.27:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.27:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.28:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.

sn56.28:1.3.pli: Dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.
sn56.28:1.3.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.28:1.4.pli: Sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya tathāgato ariyo;
sn56.28:1.4.eng: In this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, the Realized One is the Noble One.

sn56.28:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.28:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.29:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.

sn56.29:1.3.pli: Dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ—
sn56.29:1.3.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.29:1.4.eng: These are the four noble truths.

sn56.29:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ atthi ariyasaccaṃ pariññeyyaṃ, atthi ariyasaccaṃ pahātabbaṃ, atthi ariyasaccaṃ sacchikātabbaṃ, atthi ariyasaccaṃ bhāvetabbaṃ.
sn56.29:1.5.eng: Of these four noble truths, there is one to be completely understood, one to be given up, one to be realized, and one to be developed.

sn56.29:2.1.eng: And which noble truth should be completely understood?

sn56.29:2.2.pli: Dukkhaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasaccaṃ pariññeyyaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ pahātabbaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ sacchikātabbaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ bhāvetabbaṃ.
sn56.29:2.2.eng: The noble truth of suffering should be completely understood. The noble truth of the origin of suffering should be given up. The noble truth of the cessation of suffering should be realized. The noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be developed.

sn56.29:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.29:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.3:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ kulaputtā sammā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajiṃsu, sabbe te catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamayāya.

sn56.3:1.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ kulaputtā sammā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissanti, sabbe te catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamayāya.

sn56.3:1.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, etarahi kulaputtā sammā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, sabbe te catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamayāya.
sn56.3:1.3.eng: or present—rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness, all of them do so in order to truly comprehend the four noble truths.

sn56.3:2.2.pli: Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa dukkhasamudayassa ariyasaccassa dukkhanirodhassa ariyasaccassa dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa.
sn56.3:2.2.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.3:2.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ kulaputtā sammā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajiṃsu …pe…

sn56.3:2.5.pli: pabbajanti, sabbe te imesaṃyeva catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamayāya.
sn56.3:2.5.eng: or present—rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness, all of them do so in order to truly comprehend the four noble truths.

sn56.3:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.3:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation to understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.”

sn56.30:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā therā bhikkhū cetesu viharanti sahañcanike.
sn56.30:1.1.eng: At one time several mendicants were staying in the land of the Cetīs at Sahajāti.

sn56.30:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulānaṃ therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
sn56.30:1.2.eng: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from almsround, several senior mendicants sat together in the pavilion and this discussion came up among them:

sn56.30:1.3.pli: “yo nu kho, āvuso, dukkhaṃ passati dukkhasamudayampi so passati, dukkhanirodhampi passati, dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadampi passatī”ti.
sn56.30:1.3.eng: “Reverends, does someone who sees suffering also see the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?”

sn56.30:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā gavampati thero bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn56.30:2.1.eng: When they said this, Venerable Gavampati said to those senior mendicants:

sn56.30:2.2.pli: “sammukhā metaṃ, āvuso, bhagavato sutaṃ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
sn56.30:2.2.eng: “Reverends, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

sn56.30:2.3.pli: ‘yo, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ passati dukkhasamudayampi so passati, dukkhanirodhampi passati, dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadampi passati.
sn56.30:2.3.eng: ‘Someone who sees suffering also sees the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.30:2.4.pli: Yo dukkhasamudayaṃ passati dukkhampi so passati, dukkhanirodhampi passati, dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadampi passati.
sn56.30:2.4.eng: Someone who sees the origin of suffering also sees suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.30:2.5.pli: Yo dukkhanirodhaṃ passati dukkhampi so passati, dukkhasamudayampi passati, dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadampi passati.
sn56.30:2.5.eng: Someone who sees the cessation of suffering also sees suffering, the origin of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn56.30:2.6.pli: Yo dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ passati dukkhampi so passati, dukkhasamudayampi passati, dukkhanirodhampi passatī’”ti.
sn56.30:2.6.eng: Someone who sees the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering also sees suffering, the origin of suffering, and the cessation of suffering.’”
